This Emergency Response Mechanism will complement the ERM funded by ECHO and is an emergency response mechanism for Ethiopia. Funding will be made available for INGO/NGO/LNGO's to apply to in response to emergencies across the country.  While it will work alongside ECHO- ERM, it will be a separate funding pot.

Led by Action Against Hunger and including seven national and international partners, the "Consortium project to improve the well-being and health amongst the refugee and host communities in Cox's Bazar" was aimed at improving the well-being and health amongst refugee and local population in Cox’s Bazar (Bangladesh). The project aims to foster equitable and non-discriminatory access to multiple services, including community-based healthcare, nutrition, education, water supply and sanitation, and transitional shelters. The project designed through a participatory approach and implemented in close connection with target communities, especially through the partnership with community-based multi-functional centres. Specific target of the project included women, children, pregnant/lactating women, persons with disabilities, the elderly, as well as gender-based violence and conflict-affected survivors.

This opportunity is a follow on project after IRF9 emergency response - for reduced vulnerability (drought-driven displacement, illness, and mortality) and enhanced access to basic services in affected communities, including those in hard-to-reach areas.
6 months of Multipurpose Cash Assistance project to respond and provide immediate support to flood-affected populations in Balochistan and Sindh

As a follow up to BRCIS1, The BRCiS Consortium will use adaptive management and community-designed and led solutions to build resilience to local shocks and stresses. It focuses on reinforcing social cohesion and natural resource management capacities, fostering economic opportunities, and enabling access to basic services through approaches that adapt to learning, changing contexts, and community-driven priorities.

A surge of violence in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) drove large numbers of Congolese and displaced Burundians in DRC into Burundi. IRC is providing emergency protection services and material support for the most vulnerable in transit centres in Burundi. In particular, these services focus on separated and unaccompanied minors, survivors of GBV, and people with specific needs in the transit centres

A harmonized consortium approach to providing multipurpose cash assistance to effectively meet the basic needs of vulnerable conflict-affected households, reduce negative coping mechanisms, enhance access to civil documentation, and promote transition to recovery

(Description from DFUK02) Urban Refugees Advocacy and Learning Partnership (URALP) .The main purpose of the programme is to increase DFID's, its partners' and the humanitarian community's capability to better respond to urban crises.

DFID has awarded the BRCIS Consortium led by NRC of which IRC is a member funds to respond to the ongoing emergency in Somalia providing multipurpose cash as well a a health/wash interventions . IRC Somalia has been requested to respond as part of the BRCIS consortium

By increasing quality, coverage and equity of maternal and child health interventions, this program will reduce morbidity and mortality of 1,000,000 children and 330,000 mothers in Uganda and thereby contribute to attainment of MDGs 4 and 5. Strengthening the technical expertise and material capacities of public and private health providers through training, mentoring and stronger accountability mechanisms, this project will increasingly user demand and access quality services.
